------_=_NextPart_001_01C199B4.469B9950
Content-Type: text/plain

Ok I'll make a deal,

I have started on a project recently using junit, basically I am supposed to
provide support and documentation to fellow work colleagues on the use of
junit, the idea being that more people will start using junit.  Basically
its my job to navigate many of the potential problems.  Anyhow the problem I
had when beginning with junit was I found that a lot of the documentaion had
holes in it.  So I've attached here a document which describes how to write
your first junit test (it assumes junit is already installed).  Maybe you
will find it useful, and any feedback would be appreciated, Nic.



-----Original Message-----
From: Nicholas Lesiecki [mailto:nick@...]
Sent: Mittwoch, 09. Janner 2002 23:54
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Starter


yup! Although, to be fair, I did point out the excellent free documentation
too. :)

Nick

-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetev@...]
Sent: Wednesday, January 09, 2002 3:15 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Starter


nothing like a good, old-fashioned plug!

-jason
:~)

--- Nicholas Lesiecki <nick@...> wrote:
> You can also check out:
>
> Java Tools for Extreme Programming: Mastering Open Source Tools, including
> Ant, JUnit, and Cactus
>
> http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/047120708X/
>
> If you'd like a hard copy tutorial on JUnit.
>
> The link Vladimir Bossicard was reffering to is:
>
> http://junit.sourceforge.net/
>
> Cheers,
>
> Nick
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: kanti gowr [mailto:kanti11@...]

>
> Hi
> I am very new to JUnit i have just downloaded Junit3.7,i have basic doubts
> 1)where should i extract this file
> 2)what should be included in classpath
> 3)Is there sample program to test basic program
> Thanks
> Sri
